auto_merge.commit_message:
Scan all unmerged Vim commits to determine which commits are N/A
for Neovim.
vim_na_regexp.txt contains the file patterns to filter out N/A files
in a Vim commit.
vim_na_files.txt contains "absolute filepath" of N/A files.
It relies on vim_na_regexp.txt to reduce file size.
If version.c remains and it has the expected 2-liner update,
then it's considered N/A.

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/discussions/36326
auto_merge.commit_title: feat(vim-patch.sh): add n flag to list possible N/A patches (#36431)

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Scan all unmerged Vim commits to determine which commits are N/A for Neovim.
vim_na_regexp.txt contains the file patterns to filter out N/A files in a Vim commit.
If version.c remains and it has the expected 2-liner update, then it's considered N/A.

------

vim_na_files.txt contains "absolute filepath" of N/A files.
It relies on vim_na_regexp.txt to reduce file size.

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/discussions/36326

<!--
  Thank you for contributing to Neovim!
  If this is your first time, check out https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-requests-prs
  for our PR guidelines.
-->

comment_data.body:
This regexp doesn't seem to work with the latest git version. With that the `git show` command above outputs for the latest patch (which matches <https://github.com/vim/vim/commit/aa9862a5b0e68581b07197f9c21b1441ab62a290.patch>):
```diff
diff --git a/src/version.c b/src/version.c
index 78fb7bea1..df2c7f050 100644
--- a/src/version.c
+++ b/src/version.c
@@ -729,6 +729,8 @@ static char *(features[]) =
 
 static int included_patches[] =
 {   /* Add new patch number below this line */
+/**/
+    1901,
 /**/
     1900,
 /**/
```
and reversing the two lines in the regexp seems to work:
```suggestion
    grep -Pz '(?s)\+\/\*\*\/\n\+\s+[0-9]+,' |
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -886,7 +887,36 @@ review_pr() {
   clean_files
 }
 
-while getopts "hlLmMVp:P:g:r:s" opt; do
+_check_patch() {
+  patch=$1
+  cd "$VIM_SOURCE_DIR_DEFAULT"
+  # shellcheck disable=SC2126
+  VERSION_LNUM="$(git show -U0 --format="" "$patch" -- src/version.c |
+    grep '^+[^+]' |
+    grep -Pz '(?s)\+\s+[0-9]+,\n\+\/\*\*\/' |

comment_data.body:
or I extend the regexp to cover both ends. It shouldn't be dependent on the git version range.

Still need PCRE for multi-line search.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -886,7 +887,36 @@ review_pr() {
   clean_files
 }
 
-while getopts "hlLmMVp:P:g:r:s" opt; do
+_check_patch() {
+  patch=$1
+  cd "$VIM_SOURCE_DIR_DEFAULT"
+  # shellcheck disable=SC2126
+  VERSION_LNUM="$(git show -U0 --format="" "$patch" -- src/version.c |
+    grep '^+[^+]' |
+    grep -Pz '(?s)\+\s+[0-9]+,\n\+\/\*\*\/' |

comment_data.body:
Can add a new flag to only check 1 patch
but it may have more value in its own function to return the list of relevant files.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -886,7 +887,41 @@ review_pr() {
   clean_files
 }
 
-while getopts "hlLmMVp:P:g:r:s" opt; do
+is_na_patch() {
+  local patch=$1
+  local NA_REGEXP="$NVIM_SOURCE_DIR/scripts/vim_na_regexp.txt"
+  local NA_FILELIST="$NVIM_SOURCE_DIR/scripts/vim_na_files.txt"
+
+  local FILE_LNUM
+  # shellcheck disable=SC2086
+  FILE_LNUM="$(diff <(git -C "${VIM_SOURCE_DIR}" diff-tree --no-commit-id --name-only -r "$patch" | grep -v -f "$NA_REGEXP") "$NA_FILELIST" |
+    grep -c '^<')" || FILE_LNUM=0
+  test "$FILE_LNUM" -gt 1 && return 1
+  if test "$FILE_LNUM" -eq 1; then
+    local VERSION_LNUM
+    VERSION_LNUM=$(git -C "${VIM_SOURCE_DIR}" log -1 --numstat --format= "$patch"  -- src/version.c  | grep -c '^2\s\+0')

comment_data.body:
preprocess_patch() seems to work with the full patch content instead of filtering out N/A files ahead of time.

Can port an inverted version that returns applicable files for the git patch.

comment_regular_data.body: @zeertzjq Are you reviewing or is anyone in the (core) team reviewing the N/A filename/regexp lists? I posted https://github.com/neovim/neovim/discussions/36326#discussioncomment-14913419 so I can move on to other parts of vim-patch.sh and automation process for version.c PR. I did not port all filepaths from https://gist.github.com/janlazo/be3a142a642d7fd86b7166f6a3c7f206 into the new files to avoid over-guessing patches that may contain relevant code in a file Neovim didn't expect like evalfunc functions moved to non-eval files.

I get this warning when running `./scripts/vim-patch.sh -n`:
```
xargs: warning: options --max-args and --replace/-I/-i are mutually exclusive, ignoring previous --max-args value
```
And it doesn't seem to output anything for the next minute... How long does the command take?

```
time bash scripts/vim-patch.sh -n > na_patches.txt

real	1m51.801s
user	0m26.552s
sys	0m4.276s
```
Hmm, I tested it again. It runs for a bit less than 2 minutes, but then it exits with status 123 and still doesn't output anything...

I refactored xargs into while-read loop and made linenumber check more specific (in case version.c is not modified). Found more (untagged?) N/A commits.

```
time bash scripts/vim-patch.sh -n > na_patches.txt 

real	3m36.277s
user	1m10.308s
sys	0m17.320s
```

@zeertzjq Thank you for reviewing, testing, and merging this PR. 

Still, I have to ask: Did you review both files if some filepath or regexp could be applicable, instead of being marked N/A? This is meant to be the baseline so we minimize/avoid manual review.

I'm not sure if I understand the question. However I have some specific examples about preprocessing:
- If a patch's changes are limited to textprop.c and test_textprop.vim (both of which are covered by vim_na_regexp.txt), it's mostly likely that the entire patch is N/A. Example: [patch 9.1.1401](https://github.com/vim/vim/commit/56b1207e66d8db82dabf3f36aadf24caea61aa71).
- If a patch changes both drawline.c and test_textprop.vim, even though the test case in test_textprop.vim still cannot be used directly in Nvim, it may be a reference for a Lua functional test, so in this case the test_textprop.vim shouldn't be filtered out when preprocessing. Example: [patch 9.1.1798](https://github.com/vim/vim/commit/d9318acc0223bafd3ed5e7f8cdde26328bf200e7).
